description: From Middle English cheef, chef, from Old French chef, chief (“leader”), from Vulgar Latin capus (from which also captain, chieftain), from Latin caput (“head”) (English cap (“head covering”)), from Proto-Indo-European *kauput- (English head). Doublet of chef.

adjectives.description: chief (comparative chiefer or more chief, superlative chiefest or most chief)

examples: Negligence was the chief cause of the disaster.

'You’re doing it because she was your friend, not because she was a parishioner, and certainly not because of the Declaratory Articles,' Macmurray said, pushing himself forward on his seat. 'Everybody knows how chief you and she were. It was an unfitting relationship for a minister while she was alive, and it is equally unfitting for you to do her a favour like this now she's dead.'

entries.meaning: A leader or head of a group of people, organisation, etc. [from 13th c.]
examples: All firefighters report to the fire chief.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) The top part of a shield or escutcheon; more specifically, an ordinary consisting of the upper part of the field cut off by a horizontal line, generally occupying the top third. [from 15th c.]
examples: When the Chief is Charged with any figure, in blazon it is said to be "On a Chief".

entries.meaning: The principal part or top of anything.

definitionGroups.group: (sometimes ironic) An informal term of address.

entries.meaning: (US, Canada, offensive) An informal term of address for a Native American or First Nations man.

verbs.description: chief (third-person singular simple present chiefs, present participle chiefing, simple past and past participle chiefed)

examples: He chiefed on the bud like a pro, taking long deep hits and holding it within until he had inhaled as much of the weed smoke as he could.
